title: Paul Charlton (rugby league)
text:
Harold Paul Charlton (born 6 December 1941) is an English former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, and <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a>ed in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. He played at representative level for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>, <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a>, <a href="Cumberland%20rugby%20league%20team">Cumberland</a> and <a href="Cumbria%20rugby%20league%20team">Cumbria</a>, and at club level for <a href="Kells%20A.R.L.F.C.">Kells</a> ARLFC (in <a href="Kells%2C%20Whitehaven">Kells</a>, <a href="Whitehaven">Whitehaven</a>), <a href="Workington%20Town">Workington Town</a> (two spells), <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a> and <a href="Blackpool%20Borough">Blackpool Borough</a>, as a , and coached at club level for <a href="Workington%20Town">Workington Town</a>. He was part of the Great Britain squad which won the <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1972 World Cup</a>.
Background.
Paul Charlton was born in <a href="Whitehaven">Whitehaven</a>, <a href="Cumberland">Cumberland</a>, and as of 2017 he is living in the <a href="Gold%20Coast%2C%20Queensland">Gold Coast, Queensland</a>, Australia, and now plays <a href="touch%20%28sport%29">touch</a> football.
Playing career.
International honours.
Charlton won a <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a> for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> while at Salford in the <a href="1975%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1975 Rugby League World Cup</a> against France, and won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Workington in 1965 against New Zealand, while at Salford in the <a href="1970%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1970 Rugby League World Cup</a> against New Zealand (sub), in 1972 against France (2 matches), in the <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1972 Rugby League World Cup</a> against Australia, France, New Zealand, and Australia, in 1973 against Australia (3 matches), and in 1974 against France (2 matches), Australia (3 matches) and New Zealand (3 matches), during the <a href="1974%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour%20of%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">1974 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand</a> he also played 11 non-<a href="Test%20match%20%28rugby%20league%29">Test match</a>es scoring 8-tries and 12-goals for 48-points.
County Cup Final appearances.
Paul Charlton played , and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a>'s 25-11 victory over <a href="Swinton%20Lions">Swinton</a> in the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Lancashire%20Cup">1972–73</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1972–73 season</a> at <a href="Wilderspool%20Stadium">Wilderspool Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a> on Saturday 21 October 1972, played in the 9-19 defeat by <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> in the <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Lancashire%20Cup">1973–74</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1973–74 season</a> at <a href="Wilderspool%20Stadium">Wilderspool Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a> on Saturday 13 October 1973, played in the 2-6 defeat by <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Lancashire%20Cup">1974–75</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1974–75 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 2 November 1974, played in <a href="Workington%20Town">Workington Town</a>'s 11-16 defeat by <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Lancashire%20Cup">1976–77</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1976–77 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 30 October 1976, played in the 16-13 victory over <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> in the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Lancashire%20Cup">1977–78</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1977–78 season</a> at <a href="Wilderspool%20Stadium">Wilderspool Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a> on Saturday 29 October 1977, played in the 13-15 defeat by <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Lancashire%20Cup">1978–79</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1978–79 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 7 October 1978, and played in the 0-11 defeat by <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Lancashire%20Cup">1979–80</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1979–80 season</a> at the <a href="The%20Willows%2C%20Salford">Willows</a>, <a href="Weaste">Weaste</a>, <a href="City%20of%20Salford">Salford</a>, on Saturday 8 December 1979.
BBC2 Floodlit Trophy Final appearances.
Paul Charlton played in <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a>'s 0-0 draw with <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> in the <a href="1974%20BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">1974</a> <a href="BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">BBC2 Floodlit Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1974–75 season</a> at <a href="The%20Willows%2C%20Salford">The Willows, Salford</a> on Tuesday 17 December 1974, and he did not play (Frank Stead played ) in the 10-5 victory over <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> in the <a href="1974%20BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">1974</a> <a href="BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">BBC2 Floodlit Trophy</a> Final <a href="Replay%20%28sports%29">replay</a> during the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1974–75 season</a> at <a href="Wilderspool%20Stadium">Wilderspool Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a> on Tuesday 28 January 1975.
Player's No.6 Trophy Final appearances.
Paul Charlton played in <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a>'s 7-12 defeat by <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> in the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1972–73</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">Player's No.6 Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1972–73 season</a> at <a href="Fartown%20Ground">Fartown</a>, <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> on Saturday 24 March 1973.
Career at Workington Town.
In his two spells at Workington Town, Charlton made 415 appearances (Workington Town's "Appearances in a Career" record), scoring 111 tries, and kicking 77 goals, 65 of which came in two seasons, he scored 28 goals in the <a href="1965%E2%80%9366%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1965–66 season</a>, and 37 goals in the <a href="1968%E2%80%9369%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1968–69 season</a>, with <a href="Syd%20Lowdon">Syd Lowdon</a> and <a href="Jappie%20Ferreira">Jappie Ferreira</a> being the primary goal-kickers in the early 1960s, followed by <a href="Ike%20Southward">Ike Southward</a> in the mid to late 1960s, during Charlton's second spell at Workington Town, the primary goal-kicker was <a href="Iain%20MacCorquodale">Iain MacCorquodale</a> (who scored 775 goals from 1972 to 1980, including over 100 goals in 4 consecutive seasons).
Personal life.
Charlton married Lily (<a href="n%C3%A9e">née</a> Wilson) in 1965 in <a href="Whitehaven">Whitehaven</a>. They had two children: <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s, and coached in the 2000s and 2010s, Gary Paul Charlton (born 1967, <a href="Whitehaven">Whitehaven</a>), and Melanie Jayne Charlton (born 1971, <a href="Whitehaven">Whitehaven</a>).
